questions.text: If the total body water is 60% of the body weight, what are the proportions of ECF and ICF?
questions.solution:
When expressed as the percentage of body weight, 40% of body weight is in ICF (2/3rd of 60%), and 20% of body weight is in ECF (1/3rd of 60%).

The 60-40-20 rule is: 60% of body weight is water, 40% is ICF, and 20% is ECF.

Related Pearl: Body Fluids Compartments

  • In ECF, a third specialized compartment, called the transcellular compartment (not shown in flow chart), is quantitatively small and includes the cerebrospinal, pleural, peritoneal, pericardial, synovial, intraocular and digestive fluids. Altogether it constitutes about 1-2 L.
  • The ECF volume/intracellular fluid volume ratio is larger in infants and children than it is in adults, but the absolute volume of ECF in children is, of course, smaller than in adults. Therefore, dehydration develops more rapidly and is frequently more severe in children.
  • All solutes and water that enter or leave the body do so via the ECF.
  • The ICF and ECF are in osmotic equilibrium. Water moves between these compartments only when an osmotic pressure gradient exists.
  • Equilibration of ICF and ECF osmolality occurs primarily by shifts in water and not shifts in solutes.

questions.text: A 60 kg adult male has a haematocrit reading of 40% and a plasma volume of 3L. What is his total blood volume in L?
questions.solution:
His total blood volume is 5 litres.

Calculation:

Hematocrit is a percentage, as it is 40% which equals 40/100= 0.4.

(Normally, Total blood volume is 8% of body weight).

questions.text: What is the volume of blood in ml, in a child per kg body weight?
questions.solution:
The total blood volume of a child is around 75–80 ml/kg. 

In the neonatal period, it is 85 ml/kg. It rises to a peak of 105 ml/kg by the end of the first month and then drops progressively over ensuing months.

questions.text: What is the water content of lean body mass is (in mL/100g of tissue)?
questions.solution:
The water content of lean body tissue is constant at 71–72 mL/100 g of tissue.

Lean body mass = Body mass - ( Adipose tissue fat mass + Bone Mass + Non-Adipose Tissue Fat Mass)

questions.solution:

questions.text: 500 mg of mannitol was injected out of which 10% is excreted. After equilibrium, plasma concentration is 3.2 mg/100 ml. Calculate ECF Volume (L).
questions.solution:
The volume of distribution can be calculated using the formula:

  • V = volume of compartment
  • Amount injected = 500 mg
  • Amount of indicator excreted = 10% of 500 mg = 50mg
  • Plasma concentration of the indicator = 3.2 mg/100mL

Calculation:

2nd method : 

Mannitol is a substance which leaves blood vessel but can't enter the cell. Therefore, after attaining equilibrium, conc. of mannitol is same in plasma and interstitial fluid 

Therefore, by applying dye-dilution technique, mannitol can be used to measure the volume of ECF (x)

Since, 10% is excreted and 10% of 500mg is 50 mg, the amount of mannitol diluted in ECF is 450 mg (500 - 50) i.e, 450 mg is present in x 

From the given values, 3.2 mg is present in 100 ml, which can be re-written as

      3.2/100 = 450/x

Therefore x = 450 * 100 / 3.2 mL

                    = 14,062.5 mL

                    = 14 L

Clinical :

IV Mannitol is used to treat cerebral oedema (since, it doesn't cross cell membrane, it extracts fluid from brain cells), whereas it is contra-indicated in pulmonary edema (here the fluid collection is in the interstitial space)

questions.text: 10 g of inulin is injected IV and after equilibrium the concentration of inulin in plasma is 50mg/100ml. If 10% of the inulin is excreted, what is the ECF volume?
questions.solution:
Inulin is the indicator used to measure the ECF volume. (Since, inulin can cross blood vessel but not cell wall)

Calculation:

  • Since 10% is excreted, volume of inulin excreted is 1 gm. The amount of inulin diluted in ECF is 9 g ( 10 - 1) i.e, 9000mg is present in x 

    From the given values, 50 mg is present in 100ml, which can be re-written as

     

              50/100 =  9000/x

                    x = 9000 * 100 / 50 

                  = 9000 * 2

                   = 18,000mL

                   = 18L

Second method : 

  • Since 10% is excreted, volume of inulin excreted is 1 gm. 
  • Amount injected = 10g
  • Amount excreted = 1g

Now, the concentration of inulin after equilibrium is 50 mg/100ml which is equal to 0.05 g/100ml. (Convert the values into same units).

Therefore, ECF volume = (10-1)*100/0.05 =18000ml = 18 L

questions.text: A dye X which measures the plasma volume is replaced by dye Y which can diffuse out of the capillaries. Which of the following is true regarding the newly measured plasma volume?
questions.solution:
As the dye diffuses out of the capillaries, the measured concentration of the dye after equilibrium will be less. So, as per the formula, the volume measured will be falsely high. 

V = (Amount Injected - Amount Excreted) / Plasma concentration of dye

Detailed explanation: 

  • Dye x measures plasma volume:- dye x doesn't have the property of crossing blood vessel. If the dye x have been used properly, for a normal person then the value would come around 3 L
  • Dye y crosses capillaries, which means it can cross any blood vessel. This property is used to measure the value of ECF. If the dye y is given, for a normal person then the value would come around 14L
  • Thus if dye y is given in place of x, then the value would be 14 instead of 3 which is a false and the obtained value is high when compared to normal value
  • Therefore the answer is falsely high.

questions.text: Interstitial fluid volume is best measured using a combination of which two dyes?
questions.solution:
Interstitial fluid volume is best measured using a combination of inulin and Evans blue.

Insterstitial fluid is measured indirectly. ECF minus plasma volume gives the interstitial fluid value.

  • Best measure of ECF - Inulin
  • Best measure of Plasma Volume - Evans Blue (T1824)

questions.text: Which of the following is higher in the ECF compared to ICF?
questions.solution:
The pH of ECF is 7.4 while the pH of ICF is 7.0. There is continuous generation of H+ ions in the ICF due to the various metabolic processes. So, the pH of ICF is a little lower compared to ECF.

questions.text: How many grams of NaCl make 1 mole of NaCl?
questions.solution:
1 mol of NaCl is 58.5 g

  • A mole is the gram-molecular weight of a substance (molecular weight of a substance in grams)
  • In this case, the molecular weight of Na-23 and Cl-35.5.
  • 1 mol of NaCl = 23 g + 35.5 g = 58.5 g

Note

  • Each mole consists of 6 X 10 23 molecules.
  • The molecular weight of a substance is the ratio of the mass of 1/12th the mass of an atom of carbon-12. Because molecular weight is a ratio, it is dimensionless.
  • The Dalton (Da) is a unit of mass equal to the mass of 1/12th the mass of an atom of carbon-12. Thus molecular mass is expressed in units.

questions.text: How much is one equivalent of calcium (molecular weight = 40)?
questions.solution:
1 equivalent of calcium is 20 g.

One equivalent is 1 mol of an ionized substance divided by its valency.

For calcium in solution, 1 mol is going to be 40g and its valency is 2. Therefore, 1 equivalent of calcium is 40/2 = 20g.

questions.text: The unit expressing the concentration of osmotically active particles is_____
questions.solution:
The concentration of osmotically active particles is usually expressed in osmoles. Normal plasma osmolality is 280 to 290 mosmole/kg H2O

  • Example
    • NaCl dissociate into 2 particles- Na+ and Cl- in an ideal solution. Hence we can say that for every 1 mole of NaCl, there are 2 osmoles.
    • If a solute is a non-ionizing compound such as glucose, the osmotic pressure is a function of the number of glucose molecules present.
  • NOTE: The body fluids are not ideal solutions, and although the dissociation of strong electrolytes is complete, the number of particles free to exert an osmotic effect is reduced owing to the interaction between the ions. Thus, 1mol of NaCl per litre body fluids contribute somewhat less than 2 osmoles. The more concentrated the solution, the greater the deviation from the ideal solution.

questions.text: A female patient was infused with a solution which leads to rapid lysis of the RBCs. Which solution was most likely infused?
questions.solution:
Urea is a highly permeable solute, 300mMol/L urea solution behaves as a hypotonic solution.

Urea diffuses to the inside of RBC's via UTB channels very rapidly, while the rest of the solutes in the ECF cannot enter the cell. So the ECF now becomes hypotonic. So, fluid enters the RBC and causes their lysis.

Other Options :

  • Option A : The solution is iso-osmotic. (150mmol of NaCl contains 150mmol of Na+ and 150mmol of Cl- ions making the total osmolality 300 mOsm/L.This is equivalent to 0.9% NaCl which is isotonic.)
  • Option B and C: The solutions are hyper-osmotic. This will lead to shrinking of the RBCs.

Note : 

  • If a cell is placed into a hypotonic solution that has a lower concentration of impermeant solutes (<282 mOsm/L), water will diffuse into the cell, causing it to swell. 
  • If a cell is placed in a hypertonic solution having a higher concentration of impermeant solutes, water will flow out of the cell leading to cell shrinkage.

questions.text: Normal osmolarity of plasma is mainly due to ________.
questions.solution:
Normal plasma osmolarity (~290 mOsm/L) is mainly due to Na+ and its accompanying anions, principally Cl- and HCO3-

  • Osmolarity (mOsm/L) = 2 [Na+] (mEq/L) + 0.055 [Glucose] (mg/dL) + 0.36 [BUN] (mg/dL)
  • Because sodium and its associated anions (Cl- , HCO3- ) account for about 94 per cent of the solute in the extracellular compartment, plasma osmolarity (Posm) can be roughly approximated as
    • Posm = 2.1 x Plasma sodium concentration
  • With a plasma sodium concentration of 142 mEq/L, the plasma osmolarity would be estimated from the formula above to be about 298 mOsm/L.
  • In conditions associated with renal disease, the contribution of two other solutes, glucose and urea, should be included.
  • Because urea easily permeates most cell membranes, it exerts little effective osmotic pressure under steady-state conditions. (Ineffective osmoles)
  • Contribution to plasma osmolarity:
    • Na+ and associated anions: 270 mOsm/L
    • Glucose : 5 mOsm/L
    • Urea: 5 mOsm/L
    • Plasma proteins: 2 mOsm/L
    • Other ions: 8 mOsm/L

questions.text: Plasma proteins contribute only slightly to the total number of osmotically active particles because_____

choices.text: High molar concentration, high molecular weight
Low  molar concentration, low molecular weight
Low  molar concentration, high molecular weight
High molar concentration, low molecular weight

questions.solution:
Proteins actually contribute only slightly to the total number of osmotically active particles (∼1 mOsm) because of their low molar concentration and high molecular weight.

Protein concentration measured as g/L may be high. However, as their molecular weight is high, the protein concentration in terms of moles per liter ( molar concentration) will be low. Thus, they contribute only slightly to the total number of osmotically active particles.

questions.text: Which type of disturbance of body fluids is observed in sweating?
questions.solution:
Sweating→ loss of water→ Hyperosmotic volume contraction

  • The osmolarity of ECF increases because sweat is hyposmotic (relatively more water than salt is lost).
  • ECF volume decreases because of the loss of volume in the sweat.
  • Water shifts out of ICF; as a result of the shift, ICF osmolarity increases until it is equal to ECF osmolarity, and ICF volume decreases.
  • Plasma protein concentration increases because of the decrease in ECF volume. Although hematocrit might also be expected to increase, it remains unchanged because of the water shifts out of the RBCs, decreasing their volume and offsetting the concentrating effect of the decreased ECF volume.
  • So,Loss of hypotonic fluid causes hypertonic volume contraction.

questions.text: A 73-year-old diabetic man is brought to the emergency with an altered sensorium. He is dehydrated and his blood glucose is 550mg/dl. A hyperosmolar, hyperglycemic state is suspected. Which of the given formulae can correctly evaluate his serum osmolality?
questions.solution:
Calculated serum osmolality = 2 sodium + (glucose/18) + (BUN/2.8).

In the given clinical scenario, the patient with untreated type 2 diabetes mellitus has most likely developed a hyperosmolar, hyperglycemic state. His serum osmolality will be significantly raised.

The principal determinants of osmolality of serum are the concentrations of sodium, glucose and urea (blood urea nitrogen or BUN).

Osmolality is defined as a measure of the osmoles (Osm) of solute per kilogram of solvent (osmol/kg or Osm/kg). The osmolality of the intracellular and extracellular fluids is maintained between 290 and 310 mOsm in each compartment.

questions.text: Addition of 500 mL of hypertonic saline to the extracellular fluid leads to _______
questions.solution:
The images shown in the figure are called Darrow Yannet Diagrams. They depict the change in plasma osmolality and plasma volume in various conditions.

If a hypertonic solution is added to the extracellular fluid, the extracellular osmolarity increases and causes osmosis of water out of the cells into the extracellular compartment

  • ECF osmolality increases. ECF volume increases.
  • As, ECF osmolality rises, fluid from ICF moves to ECF till osmotic equilibrium is established. So,
  • ICF osmolality rises. ICF volume decreases.

Therefore, the net effect is an increase in extracellular volume (greater than the volume of fluid added), a decrease in intracellular volume, and a rise in osmolarity in both compartments.

Note : The dotted line in the diagram is the change after either addition or removal of fluid

questions.text:
The following Darrow Yannet diagram is suggestive of which condition? 
( dotted line denotes the change caused by the condition)
questions.solution:
In the given darrow yannet diagram, there is hypoosmostic volume expansion which is suggestive of SIADH.

  • So, ECF volume rises. ECF osmolality decreases.
  • ECF fluid enters ICF untill osmotic equilibrium is re-established.
  • So, ICF volume rises. ICF osmolality decreases.

questions.text: The following Darrow Yannet diagram is suggestive of which condition? Note : The solid line is the original fluid compartment and the colour shaded compartment within the dotted line denotes the change caused by the condition.
questions.solution:
In adrenal insufficiency there is hypo-osmotic volume contraction. Aldosterone deficiency leads to increased sodium loss (loss of hyperosmotic fluid).

  • The osmolarity of ECF decreases.
  • ECF volume decreases because of the loss of volume.
  • Water shifts into ICF; as a result of the shift, ICF osmolarity decreases until it is equal to ECF osmolarity, and ICF volume increases.
  • So, loss of hypertonic fluid causes hypotonic volume contraction. 

Please note that in the diagram, the horizontal axis represents volume and vertical axis represents osmolarity.

questions.text: Various safety factors prevent excessive  fluid accumulation in the interstitial spaces. Total safety factor against edema is (mmHg)_____
questions.solution:
The total safety factor against edema is about 17 mmHg.

Summary of safety factors that prevent edema is:

  • The safety factor caused by low tissue compliance in the negative pressure range is about 3 mm Hg
  • The safety factor caused by increased lymph flow is about 7 mm Hg
  • The safety factor caused by washdown of proteins from the interstitial spaces is about 7 mm Hg

        Therefore, the total safety factor against edema is about 17 mm Hg.

questions.text: You are an intern and want to determine the quantity of IV fluids needed for a patient. How much amount of transient loss/insensible loss per day would you account for in your calculations?
questions.solution:
500-600 ml of transient loss/insensible loss per day would have to be accounted for in the calculation.

Although water is lost through sweating especially in hot climates or during physical exertion, we tend to lose water at rest as well. Physiologically, water evaporates from the skin and lungs at a rate of about 600 to 700 ml/day. This is known as insensible water loss.

questions.text: I-125 labelled albumin is used for measurement of:
questions.solution:
I-125 labelled albumin is the most commonly used substance for the measurement of plasma volume.
